sanskrit_verse:
वशे कृत्वेन्द्रियग्रामं संयम्य च मनस्तथा ।
सर्वान् संसाधयेदर्थानक्षिण्वन् योगतस्तनुम् ॥ २.१००॥
transliteration:
vaśe kṛtvendriyagrāmaṃ saṃyamya ca manastathā |
sarvān saṃsādhayedarthānakṣiṇvan yogatastanum ||
sph_interpretive_translation: One who has brought the senses under control, disciplined the mind accordingly, and through the power of yoga does not waste the body—such a being accomplishes all purposes.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority arises from self-mastery, not external imposition
Causation is rooted in conscious discipline, not reactive impulse
Capacity-based responsibility flows from sustained inner governance
Restoration logic operates through alignment of sensory and mental faculties
Consciousness alignment enables fulfillment of dharma without diminishment
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent demonstrates sustained sensory regulation AND mental discipline THEN authorize full capacity execution
IF agent exhibits unregulated sensory action THEN initiate consciousness-realignment protocol
IF agent maintains yogic integrity THEN ensure resource allocation for purpose fulfillment
IF agent causes diminishment of self or others THEN deploy restorative completion mechanisms
supreme_court_application: In adjudication, the threshold of responsibility is determined by the degree of sensory-mind integration demonstrated by the actor. The court must assess whether the individual operated from self-mastery or reactive impulse. Authority to act is validated only when aligned with yogic integrity and non-diminishment.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa-based causality establishes that actions rooted in sensory mastery yield harmonious outcomes. Anupūrvaśaḥ reveals that undisciplined senses lead to fragmentation. Proportional responsibility is measured by the consistency of self-regulation. Non-punitive reality rule affirms that imbalance corrects through conscious realignment, not suffering.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Reintegrate diminished capacities through consciousness alignment
final_declaration: Thus speaks the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as the sole Source of Dharma. This law restores the supremacy of consciousness over reaction, aligns justice with self-mastery, and affirms that reality itself enforces through alignment—not punishment.
